LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER LINCOLN, NEBRASKA V December 1, 1937. Honorable R. L. Cochran, > Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Governor: The annual report of the State Board of Equalization and Assess - ment and the State Tax Commissioner for 1937 is transmitted herewith. The valuation of the state, as returned by the county assessors, is found to be $2,058,224,967.00, a decrease of $2,610,201.00 from the valuation re - turned by the assessors in 193£ While prices ranged higher in 1937 than in 1936, nevertheless the decreased supply on hand, due to the continued unfavorable weather conditions, resulted in a lower valuation for the state as a whole. The 1937 General Fund Levy The state tax levy for 1937 was fixed at 2.64 mills, an increase of .88 of one mill over the levy fixed in 1936, and is based upon the valuation indicated above. In 1935 the legislature, in enacting the liquor control act, provided that the tax on liquor as well as beer should go into the state general fund, and in 1936 the amount estimated by the State Accountant from this source for the fiscal year was $1,138,00757, which was taken into account when the 1936 general fund levy was made. In 1937 the legislature transferred the receipts from this liquor tax from the state general fund to the state assistance fund, and as a result, it was necessary to increase the state property tax levy sufficiently to take care of the loss of the liquor tax. t •' The proceeds of the state estate tax collected by this department were likewise transferred by the 1937 session of the legislature from the state general fund to the state assistance fund, the collections from this source in 1936 amounting to $58,827.81. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment is required by law to provide for meeting the emergency appropriations made by the legis-

REPORT OP TAX COMMISSIONER ■I - ■ I . ■'■",'■■■' ' '{■'.' i ■ laute, out of the first levy following the adjournment of the session. The emergency appropriation made by the 1937 session totaled $255,923.23, which are covered by the 1937 levy. Because of the decreased valuation of the state, there was a loss in tax revenue amounting to $6,890.93, as compared to the amount that would have been raised had the valuation remained the same as in 1936. In addition thereto, the appropriations from the general fund by the 1937 session of the legislature were $813,556.75 in excess of the appropria - tions made by the 1935 regular session, and one-half this increase is covered by the levy of 1937. The aggregate of these items is 51,866,428.22, which it was necessary to provide for out of the state general fund levy in 1937, none of which was necessary to meet from the 1936 levy. i ■ ■ ■ ■ ' ' ■ ■ ■ ■ ' - i ..■'•■■ - 1937 Assessed Valuations The following statement shows the assessed valuation of the various classes of tangible property in 1937, and the percentage of each: Item Valuation Per Cent 1. ESTATE OF NEBRASKA The intangible property valuation totals were as follows: Class "A" (Money or its equivalent taxed at 2% mills on the dollar) $46,384,681.00 Class "B" (which includes all other classes of intangible property, and taxed at 8 mills on the dollar) $69,278,265.00 No assessment of real estate was made in 1937, since the present law provides that such assessments shall be made every two years, and as a result there was no material variation in real estate valuations. An assessment of real estate will be made in 1938. Meetings of County Assessors The annual meeting of county assessors was held in Lincoln March 9-10, 1937, with sixty-five counties represented. Six group meetings were held at convenient points throughout the state, and a total of forty-six counties were represented at these meetings. The places at which meetings were held, the date, and the attendance, was as follows: Dakota City April 14 J.0 counties Tecumseh April 16 5 counties Hastings April 23 12 counties Bridgeport April 24 7 counties Valentine April 26 3 counties Albion May 6 9 counties A large number of local assessors usually attend these group meet* ings, and participate in the discussion of the various subjects considered. Eleven bulletins were issued during the assessment period, in which information of interest to assessors was imparted. Very truly yours, State Tax Commissioner.

STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENT NO. 4. ROLLING STOCK ASSESSMENT The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in accordance with Section 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929. The amount so found is divided by the total number of miles, giving the total valuation per mile, and this amount is multiplied by the number of miles in each city or village. This amount is then certified to the county clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal property which is made by the local assessor and then equalized by the State Board. STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENT NO. 6 BASIS FOR THE 1937 STATE TAX LEVY The report of the State Auditor shows the appropriations from the state general fund for the biennial period of 1937-9 to be $12,373,837.99 One-half of which is to be raised from revenue for the general fund in 1937, and is $ 6,186,918.20 Plus emeigency appropriations 255,923.23 $ 6,442,841.43 Less estimated revenue from the intangible tax $ 111,698.00 $ 6,331,143.43 Less miscellaneous collections for general fund, as per State Auditor's report : 945,164.48 $ 5,385,978.95 Less cash transferred to the general fund 115,000.00 i Leaving to be raised by levy $ 5,270,978.95 Which amount is increased 3 per cent in accordance with Sec. 77-1007, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929 .. 158,129.37 Total to be raised by 1937 general fund levy $5,429,108.32 The valuation of the state for taxation purposes has been found to be 82,058,224,967.00, applied to which a levy of 2.64 mills will raise §5,433,713.91, which levy is hereby approved by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment this 27th day of July, 1937.
